Knoebels Amusement Resort

Address: 391 Knoebels Boulevard Location: Franklin Township, Pennsylvania 17824

Explore the Quirky Magic of Knoebels Amusement Resort

Explore the Quirky Magic of Knoebels Amusement Resort

Knoebels Amusement Resort sits nestled in a wooded valley in Elysburg, Pennsylvania. This remarkable family-owned park has been captivating visitors for nearly a century with its unique blend of nostalgic charm and thrilling attractions. As America's largest free-admission amusement park, Knoebels offers over 60 rides and attractions without charging an entry fee - a rarity in today's theme park landscape.

From the legendary wooden roller coasters to the vintage 1913 carousel with its brass ring tradition, Knoebels preserves pieces of amusement park history while continually evolving. The park has survived devastating floods, rescued endangered rides from defunct parks, and maintained family ownership across multiple generations, all while winning prestigious industry awards for its food, rides, and overall experience.

Whether you're reaching for the brass ring on the Grand Carousel, braving the world's only wooden bobsled coaster, sampling exotic alligator bites, or simply enjoying a picnic beneath towering trees, Knoebels delivers an authentic amusement park experience that feels increasingly precious in our modern world.

Key Takeaways

  • America's largest free-admission park, spanning 45 wooded acres with over 60 rides and attractions
  • Family-owned and operated since 1926, maintaining its independent spirit and unique character
  • Award-winning wooden roller coasters including Phoenix, rescued and relocated from a shuttered Texas park
  • Home to the world's only wooden bobsled coaster, Flying Turns, where cars leave the rails entirely
  • Features one of the few remaining carousels with a brass ring tradition, undefeated in industry awards
  • Remarkable resilience, having survived multiple devastating floods throughout its history
  • Pet-friendly policies and bring-your-own-food options that make it unusually accessible
  • Award-winning food including exotic offerings like alligator bites

Overview of Knoebels Amusement Resort

Knoebels Amusement Resort has been a cornerstone of Pennsylvania's theme park landscape for nearly a century. Located in a picturesque wooded valley in Elysburg, this family-owned treasure uniquely combines old-world charm with modern excitement. Unlike most theme parks today, Knoebels maintains a free-admission policy, charging only for the rides and attractions visitors choose to experience.

A Brief History of Knoebels

The Knoebels story began long before the first ride was installed. In 1828, Reverend Hartman Henry Knoebel purchased "Peggy's Farm" for the princely sum of $931 (equivalent to about $26,638 today). His grandson, Henry Knoebel, demonstrated early entrepreneurial spirit when he noticed the property's swimming hole attracting Sunday travelers and horse-drawn hayride wagons, known locally as "Tally Hos."

Seeing opportunity, Henry began charging these visitors 25 cents to feed, brush, and water their horses while they enjoyed the natural surroundings. As the popularity of "Knoebels Grove" grew, Henry leased plots along the creeks for summer cottages, some of which still exist today, providing a tangible connection to the park's origins.

The official birth of Knoebels Amusement Park came on July 4, 1926, when Henry opened the Crystal Pool—a 900,000-gallon concrete swimming pool with a filtration system that provided clean water instead of the muddy creek water of the original swimming hole. That same year, he added a restaurant, a steam-powered Philadelphia Toboggan Company carousel, and a few simple games. From these humble beginnings, the park has expanded to include over 60 rides and attractions while maintaining its distinctive character.

The Knoebel family (pronounced "kuh-NO-bel," not "NO-bels") has retained ownership and operation of the park throughout its history, passing it through multiple generations. This continuous family stewardship is reflected in the park's uncommercial atmosphere and preservation of traditions—the park's name has always been spelled without an apostrophe on all official materials despite being the family name.

Key Features and Attractions

Knoebels offers a remarkable blend of vintage amusements and modern thrills:

  • Phoenix Roller Coaster: This award-winning wooden coaster represents one of the most famous preservation stories in the amusement industry. Originally built as "The Rocket" in 1947 for Playland Park in San Antonio, Texas, it was purchased by Knoebels in 1985 when the Texas park closed. The coaster was meticulously disassembled, transported hundreds of miles, and rebuilt in Pennsylvania. Since then, Phoenix has consistently ranked among the world's top wooden roller coasters, known for delivering remarkable "airtime" that gives riders the sensation of floating out of their seats.
  • Grand Carousel: Built in 1913 by Kremer's Carousel Works with a frame by Charles I.D. Looff and 63 hand-carved horses by Charles Carmel, this magnificent merry-go-round was purchased from Riverside Park in New Jersey in 1942 for $4,000. Today, it's one of the largest carousels in the world and one of the few remaining with a working brass ring dispenser. Riders on the outside row of horses can reach out to grab steel rings as they pass, with the lucky rider who grabs the brass ring receiving a free ride. The carousel is accompanied by three antique band organs, including "Frati," built in Germany in 1888, and has been so consistently excellent that it won "Best Carousel" in the Golden Ticket Awards every year from 2007 until 2019, when the category was finally retired because the Grand Carousel was undefeated.
  • Flying Turns: This one-of-a-kind attraction is the world's only wooden bobsled coaster. Unlike traditional roller coasters, Flying Turns features cars that actually leave the rails, controlled only by gravity as they slide up curved wooden walls. The recreation of this classic ride type took years of research and in-house development by the Knoebel family, representing their commitment to preserving amusement park history.
  • The Haunted Mansion: Built after the devastating 1972 flood, this traditional dark ride has been consistently voted one of America's best by organizations such as Dark Ride and Funhouse Enthusiasts. Interestingly, it was designed entirely by park management rather than outside vendors, and contains numerous references to the park's own history—the "attic" section originally contained actual leftover amusement park items like signs and miniature carousel horses.
  • Black Diamond: This dark ride/roller coaster hybrid is themed around Pennsylvania's coal mining history and specifically references the real-life ghost town of Centralia, Pennsylvania, where an underground coal fire has been burning continuously since 1962.
  • Unusual Attractions: Beyond rides, Knoebels offers several unique features including a bald eagle habitat, a mining museum with authentic tools and artifacts, and one of the last remaining Fascination parlors (a vintage competitive arcade game combining skeeball and bingo) in the United States.

The park has demonstrated remarkable resilience throughout its history, particularly against flooding. Located between South Branch Roaring Creek and Mugser Run, Knoebels has endured major floods in 1972, 1975, 1996, 2004, 2006, 2011, and 2018. The 1972 flood destroyed six cottages and damaged 24 of the park's 25 rides, yet through community effort, they reopened 11 rides just nine days later without accepting government assistance. In 2006, 90% of the park was underwater just before July 4th weekend, but staff managed to reopen 60% of attractions within two days and 90% within four days. These flood recovery stories have become part of Knoebels' mythology, with visible flood marks throughout the property serving as conversation starters for visitors.

Getting to Knoebels Amusement Resort

Planning your visit to Knoebels Amusement Resort is straightforward once you know how to reach this hidden gem in Pennsylvania's beautiful Susquehanna River Valley. Whether you're driving from nearby cities or traveling from out of state, understanding the best routes and transportation options ensures a smooth journey to this beloved family destination.

Location and Directions

Knoebels is located at 391 Knoebels Boulevard, Elysburg, Pennsylvania 17824, with coordinates at approximately 40.8780° N, 76.5033° W. This places it in a scenic wooded valley that straddles the line between Northumberland and Columbia Counties. The park's unique geography contributes to its charm, with the property spread across the Columbia County townships of Cleveland and Franklin on one side, and Ralpho Township on the Northumberland County side of the South Branch Roaring Creek.

For travelers coming from various directions:

  1. From I-80 West: Take exit 54 (Mount Carmel). Then, merge onto PA-15 North and drive 10 miles to the park.
  2. From I-81 North/South: Exit at 171 (McAdoo). Follow PA-15 North straight to the resort.
  3. Local roads: Use GPS for the latest directions, being aware that some older navigation systems might lead you to the former entrance on top of the hill, which was closed when road improvements included opening a new access highway with a stoplight at the lower end of the park.

The park's valley location between two creeks contributes to its picturesque setting but also makes it susceptible to flooding. When planning your visit during potentially rainy periods, checking weather forecasts is advisable.

Transportation Options

While most visitors drive to Knoebels for the convenience of having their own vehicle, there are some alternatives worth considering:

  • Personal Vehicle: This remains the most popular option, especially since Knoebels offers free parking—a policy that aligns with their overall commitment to affordability. The spacious parking areas can accommodate RVs and larger vehicles.
  • Public Transit: Limited regional bus service may be available seasonally, but these options are not comprehensive. For visitors coming from further away, the nearest major transport hubs would be in larger cities like Harrisburg or Wilkes-Barre/Scranton.
  • Shuttle Services: Some area hotels offer seasonal shuttle services to the park. If you're staying nearby, inquire about this possibility when booking your accommodation.
  • Tour Buses: During peak season, some tour companies run special trips to Knoebels, particularly for enthusiasts looking to experience the park's famous wooden roller coasters or during special events like Hallo-Fun weekends.

An interesting tidbit for visitors without personal vehicles: A travel blogger once noted that there are specific tour bus services that make the journey to Knoebels possible just two days a year, showcasing the lengths some enthusiasts will go to experience this unique park even without driving capabilities.

Arriving stress-free means more energy for tackling thrilling rides like Phoenix or for leisurely activities like picnicking in the grove. Plan your transportation wisely to maximize enjoyment of all Knoebels has to offer.

Ticketing and Pricing

One of Knoebels' most distinctive features is its approach to pricing, which stands in stark contrast to most modern theme parks. As America's largest free-admission amusement park, Knoebels offers a refreshing pay-as-you-go model that has remained consistent throughout its nearly century-long history.

Admission Prices

Unlike major theme parks that charge upwards of $100 just to enter their gates, Knoebels maintains a free admission policy. You can enter the park, enjoy the atmosphere, watch entertainment, use the picnic facilities, and browse shops without spending a penny. This approach dates back to the park's origins as a picnic grove and swimming hole, preserving a piece of amusement park history that has largely disappeared elsewhere.

For those who want to experience the park's many rides and attractions, Knoebels offers two primary options:

  • Ride Tickets: Individual ride tickets cost approximately $1.25-$3.50 each, with most rides requiring 1-3 tickets. This approach allows visitors to pay only for the rides they choose to experience. Remarkably, these ticket books look almost exactly as they did 50 years ago, adding to the park's nostalgic charm.
  • Ride All Day Passes: For visitors planning to enjoy multiple rides, wristbands offer unlimited access to most attractions. Prices typically range from $24-$48 depending on height (under 48" vs. over 48") and the specific day of your visit. These passes represent significant savings for ride enthusiasts, but aren't available on peak weekends during summer when the park is at its busiest.

It's worth noting that certain attractions might require additional fees even with an all-day pass, including the Crystal Pool and the Haunted Mansion. The latter's exclusion from ride passes is a quirky tradition that has continued despite its popularity.

For budget-conscious families, the "Sundown Plan" and "Bargain Nights" offer reduced-price hand stamps for evening visits, typically beginning at 5:00 PM on select weekdays during the summer season.

Season Passes and Discounts

While traditional season passes aren't as central to Knoebels' business model as they are at other parks, several discount options make regular visits more affordable:

  • Group Rates: Groups of 20 or more can access special pricing on ride passes, with greater discounts for larger groups.
  • Special Event Pricing: Events like Scout Day, Armed Forces Day, and other themed occasions often feature special pricing packages.
  • Ticket Sharing: Unlike most parks, Knoebels' ride tickets can be freely shared among family members or friends, and they never expire. This means leftover tickets from one visit can be saved for future trips—even years later.
  • Crystal Pool Packages: For swimming enthusiasts, season passes to the historic 900,000-gallon Crystal Pool are available at reasonable rates. Groups of 25-99 can enjoy a 20% discount on admission, while larger groups of 100+ can access special pricing as low as $5-$10 per person.

One of the most charming pricing quirks at Knoebels involves the Grand Carousel's brass ring tradition. Riders on the outside row of horses can reach for steel rings dispensed during the ride. The lucky rider who catches the single brass ring receives their ride fee back—making that particular carousel ride effectively free. This tradition dates back to the earliest days of carousels but has been preserved at only a handful of locations worldwide, with Knoebels' implementation being particularly renowned.

The value proposition at Knoebels becomes even more apparent when compared to major theme parks, where single rides might cost $5 or more when factoring in admission prices. A family of four could easily spend over $400 just to enter a major theme park, while the same family could enjoy a full day at Knoebels, including rides, food, and swimming, for less than half that amount.

Dining Options at Knoebels

After exploring the park's unique attractions or conquering the legendary Phoenix roller coaster, refueling at Knoebels is an experience in itself. The park has earned a remarkable reputation for its food, winning Amusement Today's Golden Ticket Award for Best Food for multiple years (2000-2012, 2015, 2016, 2018), often beating out much larger parks with bigger budgets.

Restaurants and Cafes

Knoebels offers diverse dining establishments throughout the park, from quick-service counters to sit-down restaurants. Unlike the standardized chain offerings found at many amusement parks, Knoebels' food service managers work largely independently, creating friendly competition that drives quality and variety.

The Alamo Restaurant serves as the park's primary sit-down dining venue, offering homestyle favorites in a comfortable setting. During special events like Hallo-Fun weekends, it hosts an all-you-can-eat breakfast buffet featuring scrambled eggs, French toast sticks, waffles, bacon, sausage, and more.

The International Food Court showcases global cuisine alongside American favorites, reflecting the diverse cultural heritage of the region. This spot gained national attention when it was featured on a Food Network special alongside the park's pizza stand.

For a taste of nostalgia, The Old Mill Ice Cream Parlor serves hand-dipped ice cream in a variety of flavors, with many visitors considering a visit to this spot essential for any Knoebels trip. Their gigantic sundaes have become legendary among regular visitors.

Smaller food stands throughout the park serve specialized offerings, from fresh-cut French fries to traditional Pennsylvania Dutch treats like pierogi (a mashed potato-filled Eastern European dumpling) and potato cakes.

Restaurant Highlights Location
Alamo Restaurant Homestyle meals, breakfast buffets during special events Central Dining Area
International Food Court Global cuisine, featured on Food Network Main Plaza
Old Mill Ice Cream Parlor Hand-dipped ice cream, giant sundaes Near the Grand Carousel
Phoenix Junction Steakhouse Grilled specialties Near Phoenix roller coaster
Oasis Cafeteria Varied menu, Friday fish fry Central location

A unique aspect of dining at Knoebels is that, unlike most amusement parks, visitors are welcome to bring their own food and beverages (no alcohol or glass containers). The park maintains free picnic facilities throughout the grounds, preserving its original identity as a picnic grove and making it more accessible for families on tight budgets.

Must-Try Menu Items

Knoebels' culinary reputation is built on several standout offerings that visitors shouldn't miss:

  • Alligator Bites: Perhaps the most famous unusual food at Knoebels, these exotic treats from the International Food Court were selected by Delish.com as one of the top seven daring amusement park foods in America. They offer adventurous eaters a unique culinary experience not typically found at family amusement parks.
  • Hand-Cut Potato Fries: A simple classic executed perfectly, these fresh-cut fries have developed a following for their consistency and flavor.
  • Pierogi and Potato Cakes: Honoring the region's Eastern European heritage, these traditional offerings provide a taste of local culture and history. The park features a special tribute to the Polish immigrants who helped build the area, reflected in some of these culinary options.
  • Homemade Fudge: Made on-site using traditional methods, the fudge stand offers a sweet treat that many visitors take home as souvenirs.
  • Unique Novelty Items: Look for distinctive offerings like pickle on a stick, caramel apple chips, and cheese on a stick—simple but beloved park treats.
  • Seasonal Specialties: During Hallo-Fun weekends in autumn, the park introduces fall-themed treats like pumpkin funnel cakes, caramel apple dip, corn chowder, and turkey legs, creating a seasonal food experience that complements the Halloween decorations and activities.

The secret to Knoebels' food success seems to be their decentralized approach. As Joe Muscato, a park representative, once explained, each food service manager works independently, creating healthy competition: "Each of them wants to have the best offerings and draw guests to their stands and restaurants." This approach has allowed Knoebels to maintain quality and variety despite being a smaller, family-owned operation.

For visitors with dietary restrictions or preferences, the diverse offerings and ability to bring your own food make Knoebels particularly accommodating compared to most theme parks, where captive audiences often face limited and expensive dining options.

Rides and Attractions for All Ages

At Knoebels, the spirit of outdoor amusement comes alive through an eclectic collection of rides that span amusement park history. From meticulously preserved classics to unique attractions found nowhere else in the world, the park offers experiences that appeal to every generation and thrill tolerance.

Family-Friendly Rides

Knoebels' commitment to all-ages entertainment is evident in its impressive array of family rides, many of which have been entertaining visitors for decades:

  • Grand Carousel: Beyond its status as an award-winning masterpiece, this 1913 carousel creates magical moments for families when children (or adults) catch the brass ring. The ride is accompanied by music from three vintage band organs, including "Frati," built in Germany in 1888, and "Berni," a 1910 Gebruder Bruder, providing an authentic soundtrack to the experience.
  • Antique Cars: Partially steered by passengers and built into the support structure of the Phoenix roller coaster, these vintage-style vehicles run on Kohler and Honda lawnmower engines. The original cars were purchased from an auction after Rocky Glen Park in Moosic, Pennsylvania closed in 1987, preserving a piece of regional amusement history.
  • Pioneer Train: This leisurely ride takes passengers through the wooded surroundings, showcasing the natural beauty that has drawn visitors since the park's days as a simple swimming hole. During Hallo-Fun weekends in October, it transforms into the "Halloween Express" with festive decorations.
  • Motor Boats: Despite the park's reputation for short wait times, this attraction consistently draws the longest lines according to park representatives, showing the enduring appeal of simple pleasures.
  • Scenic Skyride: This 14-minute ski-lift-style ride climbs a hillside beside the park, offering panoramic views of the valley and an opportunity to appreciate Knoebels' unique wooded setting.
  • Bald Eagle Habitat: An unusual non-ride attraction, this exhibit allows visitors to see these majestic birds up close while learning about their importance to the ecosystem. Educational signage explains how these birds mate for life and serve as indicators of environmental health.

Thrilling Roller Coasters and Unique Attractions

For those seeking more intense experiences, Knoebels offers several world-class coasters and distinctive thrill rides:

  • Phoenix: This legendary wooden roller coaster represents one of the greatest preservation stories in amusement park history. Originally built as "The Rocket" in 1947 for Playland Park in San Antonio, Texas, it was purchased, disassembled, and rebuilt at Knoebels in 1985 after the Texas park closed. Phoenix is renowned for its exceptional "airtime"—moments when riders feel lifted from their seats—and has consistently ranked among the world's best wooden coasters since its rebirth. Since 2018, it has held the title of #1 wooden roller coaster in the world.
  • Flying Turns: Perhaps the park's most unusual attraction, this is the world's only wooden bobsled coaster. Unlike traditional coasters where cars remain fixed to rails, Flying Turns features cars that actually leave the track and slide along curved wooden walls, guided only by gravity. Based on a ride type popular in the 1920s but extinct for decades, the Knoebel family spent years researching and developing this recreation, demonstrating their commitment to preserving amusement park history.
  • Twister: When the Knoebel family wanted to add another wooden coaster in the 1990s, they became interested in recreating Mr. Twister from Elitch Gardens in Denver, Colorado. While they initially hoped to transfer the entire coaster to Pennsylvania, they determined it wasn't in good enough condition for relocation. Instead, they purchased the original blueprints and built their own version, adapting it to fit Knoebels' unique terrain. The result includes a distinctive double-segment climb before the main drop, a necessity due to space constraints.
  • Black Diamond: This hybrid dark ride/roller coaster opened in 2011 but has an interesting backstory similar to Phoenix. The ride originally operated at an amusement park in New Jersey before being relocated to Knoebels. Its theme draws from Pennsylvania's coal mining history and specifically references the real-life ghost town of Centralia, where an underground coal fire has been burning continuously since 1962—an eerie local legend brought to life through the attraction.
  • Haunted Mansion: Consistently voted one of America's best traditional dark rides, this attraction was built after the devastating 1972 flood and opened in 1973. What makes it particularly special is that it was designed entirely by the park's management staff without help from outside vendors. The ride has evolved over time—the Skull Room originally contained music from "A Clockwork Orange," later played "Monster Mash," and now features the theme from "Halloween." True to the family ownership model, a devil featuring a plaster likeness of Pete Knoebel's face once occupied the spot where "Spooky" now resides.
  • Cosmotron: This completely enclosed Himalaya-style ride operates in the dark, combining spinning motion with light and sound effects for a disorienting thrill.
  • Sklooosh: This 50-foot-high Chute-the-Chutes water ride creates a massive wave that drenches not only riders but also spectators on the observation deck and nearby walkways—a refreshing surprise on hot summer days.

Perhaps most remarkable about Knoebels' ride collection is the way it preserves amusement park experiences that have largely disappeared elsewhere. From the brass ring tradition on the carousel to the bobsled-style Flying Turns, from the classic dark ride scares of the Haunted Mansion to one of the last remaining Fascination parlors in America, Knoebels offers glimpses into the rich history of American amusements while continuing to innovate and adapt for contemporary audiences.

Special Events and Festivals

Knoebels transforms throughout the year with seasonal celebrations that add even more character and charm to this already distinctive park. These special events have become beloved traditions for many families, offering unique experiences beyond the standard amusement park visit.

Seasonal Celebrations

Each season at Knoebels brings its own special atmosphere and events:

  • Spring Opening Weekend: The park typically opens in late April with a festive atmosphere welcoming visitors back after the winter closure. The 2025 season, for example, is scheduled to begin April 26-27, marking the start of another year of memory-making.
  • Scout Days: Throughout May (excluding Memorial Day weekend), Knoebels welcomes Scout troops from across the eastern United States for special programming and pricing. This tradition highlights the park's commitment to community organizations and outdoor education.
  • Armed Forces Day: The park honors military personnel and their families with special pricing and recognition, reflecting the park's appreciation for service members.
  • Summer Events: The core summer season features extended hours, special entertainment at the Hawaiian Bandshell, and the full operation of the Crystal Pool, continuing the tradition that began with the pool's opening on July 4, 1926.
  • Hallo-Fun Weekends: When autumn arrives, Knoebels embraces the Halloween spirit with spooky-yet-family-friendly festivities. The park gets a ghostly makeover with Halloween decorations, special entertainment, and themed food options. Some rides receive seasonal transformations, like the Haunted Antique Cars and the Pioneer Train Halloween Express. The Hallo-Fun celebration includes entertainment from the Knoebels brass band playing spooky tunes, puppet shows at the Time Machine Theater, and pumpkin-themed activities. The event strikes a careful balance, offering enough Halloween atmosphere to be festive without being too scary for younger visitors.

About This Attraction

Knoebels Amusement Resort () is a family-owned and operated amusement park, picnic grove, and campground in Elysburg, Pennsylvania.
